p:
Among all biological parameters investigated, foraging behaviour was the most variable. While little auks foraged in the same areas at the shelf break with or without sea-ice
26 , we found that diving behaviour changed with SIC: Birds performed shallower and shorter dives when SIC was the highest (Fig. 6). Thereby, dives <7 m (Fig. 5, Supplementary Fig. S2) probably reflected foraging directly underneath the sea ice, to feed on sympagic species such as Apherusa glacialis, and indeed the proportion of this species in chick diet increased along with SIC (Fig. 3d). This was also supported by preliminary results concerning birds for which diving behaviour and diet were collected simultaneously (n = 15, Amélineau et al. unpublished).
